task.title: Create a segment for marketing reports
task.shortdesc: Steps that describe how to create a segment in the Segment Definition Builder.

step.cmd: In a report or dashboard, click Add Segment.
On the Segment Definition Builder page, drag a Component (such as Visit) to the Segment Canvas.
In the Segment Canvas, click the Component (in this case, Visit).

info.p: This example shows a segment for repeat visits. This is a rule in which the visit number is greater than 1. This rule defines the report to display only repeat visitors.

step.cmd: Use the following options in the Segment Canvas to further configure segment components:

chdesc.p: The name of your segment. You can browse to locate an existing segment to use as a template.
The containers and events you can use to build a segment. Drag and drop components from Segment Definition Components to the Segment Canvas.

Stores commonly used segment definition components. To add components to your library, drag any block from the canvas on the right into this area. All details (including nested blocks) contained within that block are preserved.
Containers are used to build segments that relate to traffic data. Three types of segment containers are available:

ul.li: Page Views: Use page segments to understand the traffic going to different areas of your site, including multiple levels of hierarchy.
Visit: Use visit segments to understand the path a visitor follows and the interaction a visitor takes, such as visits that include specific pages, campaigns, conversions, and so on.

Visitor: Visitor segments are based on the visitor details, such as where a visitor comes from, buyers or window shoppers, authentication status, gender, age, geography, and so on. Visitor segmentation applies to visitor activity only during the reporting period. However, a visit could potentially include a persistent eVar from previous activity outside the reporting period. If that visitor returns to your site during the segment's reporting period, and the segment includes the eVar value, the visitor would be counted in the segment.

chdesc.p: Containers are listed in order from most granular (Page Views) to least granular (Visitors).
chdesc.note: Running an Entry Pages Report only reports on entry pages, even if you apply segment to a non-entry page.
chdesc.p: For example, assume a visit sequence is as follows:
Page A > Page B > Page C
If Page B and Page C are used in a segment, only Page A is reported in an Entry Pages Report, because Page A is the entry page.

Events are generally for conversion data and conversion events. You can make a container subordinate to an event or vice versa. When the component is in place, additional boxes appear that let you add subordinate components and more main-level components.
Specifies whether to include components (visits, visitors, referring domains, campaigns, browser type, and so on) if the requirements of the events and rules are met.

Specifies a condition that excludes components when the requirements of the events and rules that you configure are met. For example, you can set up a referring domains segment that excludes certain referrers or pages viewed.

step.cmd: Use the following options to define a segment filter rule:

chdesc.p: (Optional) The name of the component. This name carries over from the Segment Definition Builder. Changing this name does not change the core properties for the event or component. Change this name to account for the definitions you have added.
The logic rule that specifies whether all of the rules are true, or at least one of the rules are true.

Lets you use Boolean logic to create a filter for the rule. Select an event (instance, date, eVar, and so on) to use as an operator. Valid selections include:
equals: The selected item must exactly equal the value you enter.
does not equal: The selected item must not equal the value you enter.
is greater than: The value of selected item must be greater than the value you enter.
is less than: The value of the selected item must be less than value you enter.
is greater than or equal to: The selected item must equal or be greater than the value you enter.
is less than or equal to: The selected item must equal or be less than the value you enter.
contains: The item must contain the entire value you enter.
contains all of: The selected item must contain all of the values you enter, each value delimited by a space. Values are not required to be in order.
contains at least one of: The item must contain at least one of the values you enter, each value delimited by a space.
does not contain: The item cannot contain the value you enter.
is null: The field value is unknown.
is not null: The field value cannot be unknown.
starts with: The item starts with the value you enter.
does not start with: The item cannot start with the value you enter.
ends with: The item ends with the value you enter.
does not end with: The item cannot end with the value you enter.
Lets you type a value for the rule operand. You can click Select Item to locate additional items. On the resulting Select Item page, only valid values are shown.

step.cmd: After you define a segment filter rule, click Add.

info.p: The filters you create display in the Filter field. You can select an existing filter for edit.

step.cmd: On the Segment Definition Builder, type a name in the Title field, then click Save.
step.stepresult: The report refreshes with the applied segment.
